Influenza is responsible for substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide [ 1
â€“ 5]. Globally, influenza is estimated to adversely affect up to 5% to 10% of adults and 20% to 30% of children each year [ 6]. Annual influenza epidemics in the United States result in nearly 600,000 life-years lost, 3.1 million days of hospitalization, and 31.4 million outpatient visits [ 7]; in addition, the total economic burden of influenza exceeds $80 billion. Current prevention strategies for influenza are dependent on the use of anti-influenza medications and vaccines.
